author: sharknado523
body:
You bought the contract for $379

It's currently worth $503

$503 - $379 = $124

No need to exercise just sell to close.

Congratulations - profit.

As to why it says break-even is $39.79, that's because you paid $3.79 for a $36 call. So in theory, if you were to exercise this call, the shares would have to be at least $39.79 for you to "break even" considering the premium you paid.

However, since you've got like 4 months until expiry, the value of the contract is more than the difference between the strike and the market price. That difference is called "extrinsic value."

For whatever reason, your contracts are worth more now (market forces, speculation, etc.). Someone who pays $5.03 for that call breaks even at $41.03 for the same reason as what I outlined above.

Hope this clarifies for you. Think of it this way - a plate of chicken wings cost $10, but you have a coupon to buy them for $8. That coupon is intrinsically worth $2. The right to buy wings at $8 when they cost $10 is worth $2 intrinsically.

Edit: Holy karma and awards. Thank you, all!

author: marcusmv3
body:
Eats driver here. I don't hold Uber shares, but am in the wider market.

The tip thing was notified to us via the app and was said to be resolved within a week. Didn't occur to me at all though. ::Shrug::

Rides don't usually get cancelled by the customer though unless the wait times are ridiculous, and that hasn't happened to me this year except once and I was paid regardless. What does tend to happen is you'll get sent to a restaurant that has left their app online and is taking orders but in reality is closed. You might get sent up to a few miles away for a pickup that doesn't exist. Since the pickup doesn't occur, there is no payment. Annoying but only happens maybe a couple times a week.

The real thing that has pissed me off this year is that they've lowered their rates for rides, but then added in tip estimates when presenting you a ride offer. The payments per ride look about the same as they always have, except now they're not 100% guaranteed, they include what's called an 'expected tip' even though sometimes there ends up being no tip at all and now you've just made 50% less than expected on a ride.

Support calls seem to be routed to India. They've always been able to handle any issue I've thrown at them. Occasionally the customer puts in an incorrect destination address, Uber always compensates for the extra distance/time. Haven't really had to speak to them otherwise.

author: dubov
body:
Peak oil used to mean a supply side crunch because we thought we only had enough oil for a few decades left on the planet

Since fracking became a thing and we keep discovering new reserves, it became apparent that we had underestimated the potential supply

Now it seems that we may never reach a point where the supply side crunches, and instead 'peak oil' will be where we hit peak demand, which many believe may already be behind us

author: Several_tilapia
body:
In particular, investors are willing to pay more for expected future earnings because the alternatives to investing in stocks are poor.

Imagine interest rates were 10%. I could invest in Amazon and maybe their earnings would grow quickly (but maybe not), or I could buy treasuries and earn 10% a year risk-free.

Contrast with the status quo. Interest rates are about zero. The opportunity cost of investing in Amazon is lower. The rate at which I would discount future earnings is lower too. 

When interest rates are low, it's like the future is now.

author: WhatTheeFuckIsReddit
body:
i was born and raised in south phoenix and lived here my whole life, almost 30 years. while i love this neighborhood and i wouldn't live anywhere else, i understand that it is the ugliest, dirtiest, poorest and most ghetto part of metropolitan phoenix (maybe Maryvalle is worse now that i think about it). nothing good has ever came from this neighborhood except maybe some rapper in laveen that got shot and killed a few years ago, idk if he was any good, rap isn't my thing. anyway, my point is that that the schools suck, crime sucks, the houses are all old and the rare new construction is cheaply made.

so when i hear a friend of mine made 5 figures on NKLA calls i investigate the company. and lo and behold it's headquarters are right here in my neck of the woods. 40th street and broadway. when i tell you that this industrial park is in one of the worst parts of town i mean that there are hookers walking up and down this area of broadway road every night, boarded up houses with shot up facades, vacant lots behind tagged alleys with burned cactus that some poor tweaker tried to light up to stay warm during winter.

i drove by a few weeks ago on a random wednesday afternoon and the parking lot was less than a quarter full of cars. a "delivery entrance" that was taped off for some reason, and no real sign of life. 

i'm not some huge shortseller like hindenburg i'm just their neighbor, and no multi-billion dollar tech startup is gonna be here no matter how cheap the real estate is.

10 upvotes and i'll go walk into their front office and ask for a job application and say "i want to be the guy that pushes the cars down the hill"

&#x200B;

NKLA  **9/18/20 25P**

author: Tumirnichtweh
body:
Sounds like a rumour to increase early sales for PS5 or stock manipulation.

**Why is this unlikely?**

TSMC 7nm has a very good yield. Defect density was 0.09 9 month ago. As it is constantly improving, I assume 0.07 now.

Lets assume ps5 die is similar size to xbox die. (no exact info on ps5 die online)

Input all values into the wafer calculator here:

[https://caly-technologies.com/die-yield-calculator/](https://caly-technologies.com/die-yield-calculator/)

This results in a yield of 80.5%. Add some partial functions dies as well, as usually console chips have  some redundant compute units to increase yield. So between 80.5 and 85% yield.

Even if we make it 20% larger than xbox die, we wont even come close to 50% yield.

To drop below 50% yield, the defect density must be 0.23 which is not the case for 7nm.

I see no technical reason why it should be 50% yield. The article also provides no explaination why yield should be that horrible on a mature node with low defect density. They are not even trying.

Maybe any electrical engineer can chime it, if there are other reasons why yield could be that horrible on a mature node besides defect density and die size?

author: DeltafrogB69
body:
Be grateful you learned as much as you have without losing life-crippling sums of money. Some people learn the exact same lesson as you but spend $100k in the process. Remember that you aren't a savant trading genius. Much more experienced people than you are struggling in a wacky market like this. It's a casino for everyone. You're just the lucky guy who walked into the casino with money he could afford to lose instead of throwing your whole student loan on the roulette table.  Don't be upset, be very glad. The education you just got was a lot cheaper than what many others pay to realize they're retarded.

If you decide to get back on this mentally handicapped horse, discard any regret and pity about what happened so far and just consider it a modestly priced lesson. Stick to playing with money you can afford to lose rather than getting caught in pitfalls like FOMO and dragon chasing and margin trading. Learn more about the fundamentals and consider strategies that aren't as radical as the ones that autists here encourage. If you don't like the feeling of the rollercoaster ride and its periodic whipe outs, then look into how Theta gang and r/investing operate. Its less of an adrenaline rush, but you won't have to feel like how you do right now ever again.

I think you'll look back one day and realize that in the scheme of things, where you are right now isn't the rock bottom that you think it is. Imagine if you got crazy lucky on your last few trades and started feeling like a genius. You'd take whatever sum of money that was, then gamble it again, eventually lose it, and feel even dumber. The worst thing that can happen at the casino is winning big on your first trip, because then rationality goes out the window and you're hooked like a sucker. Its better that you got a cheap reality check now so you can focus on proper fundamentals and have a real strategy instead of just emulating the worst behavoirs of the retards here.

author: thats_your_name_dude
body:
I think there is a more important question you aren’t asking.

The question isn’t if Boeing will eventually recover. The question is:  if you pulled all your money out of Boeing, right now, and invested in the broader market (i.e. S&P 500), would you make more money, or not, over your time horizon.

If you think that Boeing will outperform the market in that time horizon, hold it. If you assess that you will make more in the broader market, even if you have to sell Boeing for a loss, then do that. It may be many years before Boeing returns to its former strength (if at all), and the market as a whole may see serious gains in the meantime. You must make that decision, and it is a difficult one.

Unfortunately, I was in a similar position a few years ago when GE shit a brick. I sold it at $20/share. For me, it was 15% loss overall.

However, I made the assessment that the SP would trounce GE’s returns for at least five years, maybe more. Really glad I made that decision, because last time at checked, GE was six bucks a share. But at the time, it was a very tough call, and it took a few months to become comfortable with the decision I’d made.

author: Caleb_Krawdad
body: Itd have a different effect. And the fact that banks cant foreclose on someone's degree adds a wrinkle to it as well. Theres no real impact of "foreclosing" on a student loan other than the credit hit and then the big banks obviously losing out on that money. So you'll likely see them keep the loans open and keep dragging out payments.  As a result rates in other areas likely will increase 1 to offset the student loan losses but more so 2 because the base of borrowers now has more debt and is more risky.

author: rightovahere
body:
If you're a multinational that does business in a foreign country or region, you need to comply by that regions laws. You can't just tell a country to fuck off unless you want to be barred from doing business in that country for an indefinite period of time.

Nobody gives a fuck if Paraguay tells Nvidia that they'll have a monopoly, but they sure do if the USA or CN does.

China killed the qualcomm NXP merger a few years back due to antitrust concerns (and potentially some trade war fuckery), and that wasn't nearly as excessive compared to this. Nvidia controlling ARM would be insane.

body:

author: jorlev

author: kaposai
body: They could go ahead with the deal ignoring any oposition from China. But guess what, China could deny them doing business in China. This is why Qualcomm had to pull out of the NXP deal. Qualcomm couldnt afford losing their Chinese customers.

author: ImagineInfinity12345
body: Bizarrely, the ones with solid growth potential and a track reccord of earnings, but the ones people think this new age of tech stocks is going to displace. Question is, are they right. Take Paychex for example.

author: Sir_Dink
body:
>ADP only releases private numbers it has.

Pretty much this.

I don't know any small business owner who uses ADP. Mostly it's between Paychex and Square.

They likely have some way of extrapolating an estimate for the missing payroll data, but since covid effected small business payrolls disproportionately it likely messed up their method of divining the data they don't have.

author: UpSideofDown
body: Here’s my leaps shopping list:  COST, PAYX, PEP, JBHT, VZ, PYPL, SQ, PLD.  Sure bets looking at any of their charts...

author: Sir_Dink
body:
>Lots of places just straight closed and stopped running payroll but they didn't notify them of employee additions/subtractions.

Atleast from experience with Paychex self service, some fees are related to current head count. It makes little sense to not inform 3rd party payroll services you furloughed all workers and closed.

author: HAC522
body:
My bad, guys. I did the math and determined QCOM was consistently going up at least 10 bucks every single month, with lots of good news to support the rise. Therefore, I bet down on some totally reasonable 10/2 130c's yesterday. 

So, of course, that's why the tech sector tanked.

author: MrMineHeads
body: His valuation was pretty ass tbh. Plus who thinks that Intel is gonna double revenue in 10 years with competitors as fierce as AMD, Qualcomm, and others. Honestly, good luck. My rough DCF analysis put it has like $55/share, with 7% growth in revenue per year for 5 years (a generous amount).

author: BeastInfection
body: Agreed, QCOM, TSM, among others just lost billions in future investment from selling chips to China. TSMC is the big loser in this since new nodes are so crazy expensive now and they need crazy volume to drive down cost of production and still have enough to invest billions in the next node. Samsung is also a huge loser. I bet you they were almost excited for a few hours at the TSMC/Huawei ban, before realizing they would probably be covered as well.

author: happierdayz4me2
body:
Yeah, pre earnings. Then averaged then theta and lack of volume/movements nullified the 2k in gains that were trying to offset the initial 5k losses. I was promised stonks only go up and I was unaware that good news and fundamentals = sell off. 

Made a nice chunk off qualcomm and tup but my positions were limited by how much I sunk into atvi sept calls.

body:
I mean, I do make bets.  They are just slow developing.  I'm long WMT, DISCA, JNCE, and got QCOM at a decent price so I'm holding.

I'm building/shifting into EDV right now. So I'm starting to bet the economy is going to drag this market down after all (also, decent chance of overreaction to the election/aftermath).

body:
I'm with you on concern for the market correction, aside from ATVI, im mostly in leaps for 5G, call wise. Qualcomm has made me a lot recently. 

As for how how ATVI will perform under a correction, I think it will fare better than most. The minor pullback today didn't phase atvi and it feels almost impervious* (I know it's not). It is at ATH levels so that is a risk, but it's fundamentals make it not crazy overvalued going into its best holiday season. Santa comes recession or not. If trump is reelected tech stocks should stay afloat into the winter (not an economist) and if biden wins, he'll give everyone enough money to buy a console and blow a wad on microtransactions.

author: gravycap
body:
Where I live i am not legally allowed to trade in the stocks. But recently few new web services has allowed me. Almost everyday i would think about investing in the us stocks but I had to settle for stocks in my own country. I did lot of study my thesis everything on this topic. So on 22/06/2020 i started. Not a great time to enter. Made few mistakes at the beginning because of excitement.

I can't predict every ups and downs. This one is very similar to 1999/2000. Check CSCO and QCOM chart for the period. You will see amazing similarity. And if you are asking why these stocks they were the market leaders of the time and their split marked the beginning of a bear market.

author: sleepyguy007
body:
intel, cisco, qualcomm, juniper etc were all huge bubble stocks in the tech bubble and were making tons of money.  


This tech bubble is just as bad and the same sort of mix of unprofitable companies, profitable overvalued companies, and now people just trying to cash out as fast as possible via SPACs and IPOs as there was then.  It might not be quite as steep a bubble yet, but its definitely getting there.  it took 4 years to go from 1200 -> 5000 in 2000.   4 years ago the nasdaq was 5000 or so, so I could see it gettingto even 15000 and then crashing.  maybe not quite as big, but still as someone above mentioned economic conditions are far far worse now and we have much more debt than we did in 2000 as a nation

author: BumbleFuckDuck
body:
Article from link:

"Zomedica Pharmaceuticals Corp. (NYSE American: ZOM) announced today that it has agreed with its development partner Qorvo Biotechnologies, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Qorvo US, Inc., to develop three new assays -- Cobalamin, cPL (canine Pancreatic Lipase), and Folate -- to target diagnosis of canine gastrointestinal issues. The new assays are in addition to the initial five assays currently under development, including panels for adrenal and thyroid testing, for TRUFORMA™, Zomedica's point-of-care veterinary diagnostic platform. The agreement to pursue development of the new assays has triggered the final $2 million milestone payment under Zomedica’s Development and Supply Agreement with Qorvo.

“Our intent for TRUFORMA™ always has been to have it serve as a broad diagnostic point-of-care tool for dogs and cats and to continue to expand the diagnostic offerings available on the platform," said Robert Cohen, Interim Chief Executive Officer of Zomedica. "We believe that the combination of the Cobalamin, cPL and Folate assays will enable veterinarians to use TRUFORMA to conduct a thorough testing panel to diagnose dogs in gastrointestinal distress."

If successfully developed, the Cobalamin, cPL, and Folate assays will represent what the Company believes is the first non-infectious gastrointestinal panel optimized for use in canines fully available at the point-of-care to facilitate rapid diagnosis of gastrointestinal disorders. Evaluation of the health of different components of the gastrointestinal system is necessary to identify the cause of clinical symptoms. This panel is intended to assay the function of the pancreas, proximal small intestine, and distal small intestine. The Company believes that the ability to conduct testing at the point-of-care will facilitate real-time clinical decision-making, reduce in-patient clinic stay, promote earlier detection and treatment, and increase pet owner satisfaction.

According to a DVM360 study*, ASPCA Pet Insurance, Embrace, Nationwide, Pets Best and Trupanion agree that “GI condition” is the most common insurance claim for dogs. Signs of digestive system disease can include excessive drooling, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting or regurgitation, loss of appetite, bleeding, abdominal pain and bloating, straining to defecate, shock, and dehydration. The TRUFORMA diagnostic device, which is smaller than a desktop printer, is anticipated to provide highly sensitive, species-specific assays using Qorvo’s proprietary, non-optical Bulk Acoustic Wave ("BAW") sensor technology. The BAW sensor is a proven semiconductor technology used in telecommunications and aerospace markets. The Company believes that BAW technology has the potential to improve veterinary diagnostics by delivering reference laboratory accuracy and test performance to the veterinary clinic at the point-of-care."

I bolded the important parts. This is a long hold regardless if r/s happens or does not. IMO the r/s ain't happening.
